title: 107_hr999
content: The "Rail Merger Reform and Customer Protection Act" amends Section 11324(c) of title 49, United States Code, to ensure that rail mergers do not reduce competitive routes, provide more rail competition options, improve customer service, and comply with antitrust laws. The Surface Transportation Board must consult with the Attorney General before making any antitrust law findings. The amendments to Section 10501(b) of title 49, United States Code, state that rail carriers and transportation under the Board's jurisdiction are subject to antitrust laws. This does not limit remedies available under this part. Additionally, all orders and permits issued by any agency must comply with these laws. The Rail Merger Reform and Customer Protection Act ensures that existing orders and permits remain in effect until modified or revoked by the relevant authorities. The definition of 'antitrust laws' in Section 10102 of title 49, United States Code, is also amended to include section 5 of the Clayton Act. The definition of 'antitrust laws' in Section 10102 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to include section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act. SEC. 4. RATE AGREEMENTS. Amendments to Section 10706 of title 49, United States Code include removing references to antitrust laws and making conforming amendments to chapter 107. Amendment to section 10706 of title 49, US Code includes removing reference to antitrust laws in the table of sections for chapter 107. SEC. 5. SCOPE OF AUTHORITY amended to include rail carriers and rail transportation under the jurisdiction of the Board subject to antitrust laws. SEC. 6. ELECTION OF REMEDIES amended to prevent double proceedings against rail carriers under different laws for the same claim. SEC. 7. CLAYTON ACT AMENDMENTS. The Clayton Act is amended to remove references to the Surface Transportation Board in sections 7, 11, and 16.
